territory.notes: Although it may have been encountered by Icelandic sailors in the late 1190s (and claims of first contact were made by Russian and United Kingdom authorities), the first official record was put down by Dutch explorer William Barents in 1596. Svalbard was first settled by whalers in the early 1600s. Over the subsequent centuries, various nations and corporate interests established claims upon the archipelago–which was rich in whales, walrus, and coal. Colonies associated with various nations and corporations were established at this time–the Dutch, Danish, and United Kingdom made exclusive claims upon the islands at various times but were never able to enforce them thanks to the geographic isolation and extreme climate of the area. An informal arrangement persisted where particular bays and villages were operated exclusively by different national and corporate bodies. Over time, additional nations and corporations supported by national governments (particularly Norway, Russia, and the United States) established outposts in Svalbard. In 1872, Sweden-Norway and Russia exchanged notes declaring the territory a terra nullius-a ‘no man’s land’ which had never been and was not presently subject to the sovereignty of any state. A draft convention was prepared in 1912 formalized the territory’s status and proclaimed that it could not be annexed by any state. This anarchic state of affairs proved untenable in due course–most particularly when various companies began to claim mining rights in the early 1900s–and a conference was assembled in Christiana (present day Oslo) in June 1914 to determine control of the islands. While the assembled nations could not agree (either here or in a series of subsequent conferences) which nation should possess it, all previous claims were held to be void and the terra nullius status upheld. This highly unusual state of affairs attracted the interest of no less a luminary than future Secretary of State Robert Lansing who wrote of “This extraordinary political state of the islands, to which a parallel will be hard to find in modern times.” In 1920, as part of the post World War I Versailles process, Svalbard was granted to Norway under the terms of the Svalbard Treaty. This grant was somewhat limited as the treaty contained equal enjoyment and liberty of access provisions for signatories and functionally created a demilitarized zone around the islands. Furthermore, not all Norwegian laws apply to Svalbard.
